comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Another bit of aircraft nerding from me. The one on top is a Shorts S20. Below is an S21. Both aircraft were passed on to BOAC in 1940. The S20 was broken up at Rochester in 1941. The S21 was destroyed in an air raid at Poole during WWII.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: There was a special stamp and first day of issue for this event and I have a postcard sent by my father to his cousin in the US and asking that it be returned to him sometime.  It was but much later as the cousin was on military service and took part in WWII.  He returned it personally in the early 60's when he and his family visited Ireland.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
Major Mayo of Imperial Airways developed the idea from 1932 onwards of using a large flying boat to lift a small fast mail plane to operating height. It took until 1938 before a suitable four-engined floatplane was designed to Mayo's design and at the same time an existing Shorts flying boat was modified to act as the launch platform. The smaller mail carrier was named Mercury and the larger launch flying boat Maia. 
In July 1938 Mercury was launched over the River Shannon and flew direct to Montreal with 2,200 pounds of mail. However, the British Air Ministry, who had partially funded the experiments, decided there was no future in the project, and although Mercury was launched by Maia late in 1938 on two flights to Alexandria carrying Christmas mail, that was the end of the experiment.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Any idea what happened to them, Bob? Surely they weren't just scrapped?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
The S20 (smaller one) was broken up at Rochester during WWII for it's aluminium. 
The S21 (bigger one) was destroyed in an air raid at Poole also during WWII.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Sad! So they only really "lived" for a few years after this photo was taken...

comment.author: 11500904@N04
comment._content: Oh dear. This composite was not aimed at getting a heavy aircraft into the air after a short takeoff run. THe problem to be solved was how to fly across the Atlantic, when neither aircraft had the required range.

comment.author: 101928474@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/$176971536@N08$1]  Hi, great topic and thought it would be great to hear from you with your connections to the Mayo Composite as we are about to open a new Imperial Airways museum. I look forward to hearing from you. Best Wishes, Neil

comment.author: 101928474@N08
comment._content: My previous comment was for 'picnic50' who's grandfather flew the Mayo Composite

comment.author: 101928474@N08
comment._content: Dear Vivionm - the composite idea was to get the upper aircraft into the air and to height. Without having to take off on its own it could then get across the Atlantic in one go. It is amazing the difference it made, and the lower component (the mothership called Maia) purely returned back to base after separating. The smaller aircraft, called Mercury, not only flew across the Atlantic but also down to South Africa non-stop, which to date is still the longest sea plane flight ever made.
